title.narrative: Enhancing Rapid Disaster Response for Flooding in Timor-Leste

description.narrative: On 4 April 2021, severe flooding following a torrential downpour caused widespread flooding in Timor-Leste. Preliminary official figures indicate that a total of 2,065 households – or approximately 10,325 people - have been affected across 8 municipalities in Timor-Leste. The flooding adversely impacted livelihoods, and essential services, including private shelter and public infrastructures, such as schools, health and sanitation facilities, water and energy provision, as well as roads and bridges. Families whose homes were completely destroyed face many challenges to cope and progress into recovery, often due to the lack of means to rebuild their homes. The overall aim of the project is to contribute to the national response and meet the immediate needs of flood affected populations in Timor-Leste. To do this, the project is addressing the immediate needs of the affected populations who have lost critical household items and whose homes were destroyed or damaged, create a conductive environment for camp coordination and camp management and shelter coordination and interventions and ensure that stakeholders have access to timely information on living conditions, needs of the affected populations dealing with displacement and return trends.

participating-org.narrative: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

mailing-address.narrative: UN House, Building 09 Caicoli Street, Dili, Timor-Leste

sector.narrative: Movement, Emergency and Post-Crisis Migration Management

policy-marker.narrative: Project with some but insufficient inclusion of gender issues

provider-org.narrative: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)
